column4: good idea or bad idea: install project looking glass on feisty fawn
i dont know about fawn, i installed it on edgy, scary buggy. hosed my system worse than beryl
i haven't had any problems with beryl at all..
i havent had to many problems with beryl either personally, but tons of people had trouble stopping it from screwing x, thats what looking glass did for me :D'
i also know that they used to have a demo of looking glass so that you can play with it, but it doesnt install anything
next time research your overpriced hardware before you pay for it :P
nothing is great in windows.
i hate you
what keeps you from using linux for everyday stuff?
nothing i suppose, its just annoying to have to boot into windows to do my audio work, and, i hate having two speaker sets hooked up
linux audio studio software not good enough? not a sarcastic question, im looking for solutions in linux too.
no the software is pretty ok, its onboard sound that isnt ok
horrible latency and the like
my onboard doesnt seem to have a problem with latency but i haven't put much of a strain on it
sound quality isnt bad with onboard, i just lose the useful features, like 24-bit audio, low latency, multiple controlled inputs
yeah, i do a lot of live recording though, guitar and midi keyboard plugged in, as well as vocals
me too but always just 1 at a time

i wouldnt have an issue if i used a hardware controller for say my guitar, running it through a pedal for processing, but, as of late i have been using guitar rig, without the rig, requires a lot of processing
in reason though, if i were to do some live processing with midi control, with certain effects, it helps alot to have the extra processing of an external card
thats probly true too.
anyhow, thanks for the help. I suppose ill live with booting back and forth for now. I still dislike windows for web surfing. in fact, i get pissed at windows after using linux for a while. lol.
one more question. any recommended software packages for audio in ubuntu?
i use Jokosher and MuSE
